bone density abnormality/lesion: Areas of increased or decreased opacity in bones; can appear as sclerotic (whiter) or lytic (darker) regions.
spinal curvature abnormality: Curved or rotated spine, typically visible as a deviation from the midline (scoliosis) or abnormal front-back curvature (kyphosis/lordosis).
device/foreign body: Dense, well-defined structures not normally present; examples include pacemaker leads, central lines, or ingested objects.
postoperative change: Surgical alterations like sternal wires, missing ribs, or resections; visible as metallic artifacts or anatomical distortions.
increased density: Localized or diffuse areas appearing whiter than surrounding tissue, suggesting fluid, mass, or collapsed lung.
fibrotic band: Linear, dense streaks indicating old scarring, often peripheral and thin.
cardiomegaly: Enlarged heart silhouette, where the cardiac width exceeds half the thoracic width.
atelectasis: Collapse of lung tissue, seen as increased density with volume loss and displacement of nearby structures.
infiltrate/consolidation: Patchy or dense opacification without volume loss, indicating infection (e.g., pneumonia) or other causes.
air trapping/hyperinflation: Flattened diaphragms, increased retrosternal airspace, and barrel-shaped chest indicating obstructive lung disease.
hiatal hernia: Air-fluid level or soft tissue mass behind the heart due to stomach herniation into the thorax.
pleural effusion: Homogeneous opacity in the lung base, often with meniscus sign and blunting of the costophrenic angle.
nodule/mass: Focal round opacity (nodule <3 cm, mass >3 cm) within the lung fields.
interstitial pattern: Fine reticular (net-like), nodular, or reticulonodular opacities suggesting interstitial lung disease.
fracture: Sharp discontinuity or irregularity of bone structure, sometimes associated with adjacent soft tissue swelling.
pleural thickening: Smooth or irregular increased density along the pleural surface, often from prior infection or asbestos exposure.
hilar enlargement: Widened or bulky hila due to lymphadenopathy, vascular congestion, or tumor.
